document.text: With Spring fast approaching, plans are underway for the 1964 Dixie Youth Baseball program, which will be conducted again this year at the recently improved Appomattox Town BallPark.  Three leagues are offered for male and. female athletes this season Boys ages 13 and 14 Pre-Majors ages 15 and 16, and Majors ages 17 and 18. Registration is beings conducted at Best Furniture Company, on Highway 460 east of the town of Appomattox,

document.text: Wf F r a n c e s  h . P a u l e t t e  It you were to stop by the home of Gilbert M ay, just off of highway 460, after hes finished his job at Transco, you. most likely wouldnt find him at home.   iW ?- Inquiring of his wife, Irene, as to his whereabouts, you might get an answer something like this, hes busy with his honey! Oh yes. Gilbert Mays lovés his honey.....and the approxi mately Ï75 hives of bees that produce that honey. . Mays has a fascinating avocation, beekeeping. Hes been at it for approximately fifty years. His late grandmot her Moitié Mays, who inciden tally lived to be 102, raised bees in a nail keg. Whenever the bees swarmed and she had to get them in a hive, she would call her grandson, Gilbert and he would , come and help her. From the early age of six or seven he became more and more interested in the art of beekeeping. Beekeeping is just what the name suggests the man merely keeps the busy little beës...Al- though they may live in his hive, he, in no way owns them. In a most independent manner they go about their business pollinating the  flowers and giving-honey for man to enjoy. If the bees wanted, they could easily swarm away from a particular hivnand relocate somewhere else but not only are they industrious, they are smart. If the beekeeper is doing his job property they know their surroundings are good and they will stay there. Man, in a sense, may manipulate the bees, but he is not able to improve on their work or further glorify the results of their efforts. Bpes are efficient, loyal, handworking and even rather intelligent, despite their tiny size. Cont rary to popular belief, they are quite docile. Beekeeping and honey prod uction go hand in hand with the miraculous cycle of nature. No day for beekeeper Gilbert Mays is ever quite the same. His avocation holds a fascina tion as no other hobby could do. He is constantly rewarded by his efforts. The modern beehive is a series bf boxes stacked atop one another inside each of these boxes hang frames in which the bees build their hexagonal-cell- ed combs. The bottom sets of boxes are actually working and living areas for the colony bf bees all the boxes stacked above called supers are placed there by the beekeeper for the bees to fill with honey. Three types of bees live in the colony the queen bee, the drones, and the worker bees. The queen bee, which lives fortwo or three years, exists primarily to My - eggs. She . mates only onee, and is then capable of laying 1500 or more eggs every toy until her death. She is the center of attention for the hive when she is nearby, all the other bees exhibit a particularly excited behavior. They feed her, raise1 her young, mid protect her. When she dïé, without warning, the rest of the colony actually makes Sa audible wailing sound that they make t no, other tuïj. Yet, if the other bees aeffii that their qneens usriftjKrtÉ to waning,

document.text: Webbs Tire Company had its beginning in December of 19f8 when Martin L, Webb opened Webbs Esso Service to the rid Number Three Service Station on Highway 460 East. Martin had been working for several years with the Standard Oil Company and was anxious to return to his native Appo mattox when this business opportunity arose.  Concentrating at first on oil related products and gasoline, Webb soon became more and more involved With the tire business. In the early 1950s Webbs Esso opened the first retread plant in Appomattox. As business grew , it became evident that expand ed facilities would be needed to meet the growing demand for retreads and new tires in Appomattox County, In  1958, WebbS Tire Company moved into a new facility on W est Confederate Blvd. Further additions were built in 1966 and in 1974.  In 1974 Webbs Tire Company was recognized for its quality retreads by winning two blue ribbons at the American Retreaders Associations worldwide re tread appearance contest. This was quite an accom

document.text: Vepco has announced a plann - ed power outage for its custo m ers in the Appomattox area on Saturday, June 10, 1972. The outage will include Vepco cust omers from Pamplin and extend west along Highway 460 through Appomattox to Concord. Vepco customers north of Appomattox are included in the power out age. Appomattox and Concord residents can expect approxi mately one hour of power out age beginning at 500 a.m. June 10, 1972. Vepco customers from Appomattox back to Pamplin will have an extended outage of approximately three to four hours. The power outage is neces sary so that improvements may be made to Vepcos power lines in that area. Vepco appreciates its customers understanding during this necessary change.

document.text: There was no génération gap when the Appomattox Young Hearts Club performed with their musical instruments for the pre-school children at the Appomattox Childrens Center on highway 460 Wèst. The children thoroughly enjoyed the music and in turn presneted some of their songs for the Young Hearts Club members. Following the program there were lots of smiles and hugs for everyone, commented Mrs. Merle ODonnell, who with her husband Brian owns the childrens day care center.

document.text: the crusade to invite Tommy and Bob back to continue evangelistic meetings on June 5 at the ACHS Auditorium . Meetings will move to the Appomattox County Elemen tary School Auditorium on Highway 460 beginning Tues day, June 6. Hie Crusade will begin promptly at 8 p.m. Bob Ward, Crusade Choir Director, invites anyone interested in sing ing in tiie choir to meet at 7 p.m. nightly for rehearsal. Everyone is invited to attend this great interdenominational crusade.

document.text: Sept. 25, 1972 Dear Mr. Editor I write first as a Christian, second, as a citizen of this Commonwealth and of the United States of America, as well as a taxpayer, third, be cause of the chaos, unrest and confussion in our midst and Nation at large, the once greatest Nation under Heaven, the land of the free and home of the brave, and still is, if we, as a Nation will only honor and obey Almighty God. Psalm 9-17. The many things going on in our community and Nation, that are absurd and ridiculous that the majority of our people do not want, and most certain ly do not approve, a three mil lion dollar school, the taxpay ers, said No, the Supervisors, skyrocketing our taxes, for what will never bring about Quality Education. Funda mental down to earth Educa tors declare that mixing the races can never improve education, but lower or destroy it to both races. The next most ridiculous and unnecessary proposal by this Commonwealth, is a three mil lion dollar Highway by-pass to kill Historic Appomattox, just like they killed Pamplin, the only other major town in Appomattox County, with a very unnecessary by-pass, which has also been a death trap. No small town needs a by-pass, they need all the outside traffic they can get, all they need is to maintain a four-lane Highway through the towns, with proper lights where necessary, with only a fraction of the cost of unnecessary by-passes. The larger cities need by-passes, but they are unessential and absolutely unnecessary for small towns, to site an instance of the need of a by-pass, my wife, and I returning for West Virginia, recently, thru Staun ton saw the need, a large city as that is, has no bypass, you have to wind around all the way thru the city to get to Interstate 81. There a by-pass is essential and needed, but I hear of none being proposed for that large city, where the need is great. When will our leaders ever wake up to the facts, that we, taxpayers do not want our money spent on such useless and unnecessary projects? Another even more absurd proposal by this Common wealth, is to construct a new bridge and road in a slight new location, across the Norfolk and Western Railroad, on se condary road 635. The old bridge could be strengthened and widened, or removed entirely, detouring the traffic, and a new one put in approximately the same loca tion and with safety to the public, if common sense were exercised. I received a letter from the Virginia Highway Department stating the road bed of this proposed new bridge will be nine 9 feet higher than the roadbed of the present bridge. Think of approximate 9 foot fill on each end of this bridge, with the short distance on the North from main Highway 460, such an unreasonable rise in elevation will make it virtually unsafe for any traffic in the winter, or even when the road is wet, wheh entering 460 would be almost impossible to stop for on-coming traffic, yet they are proposing to trans port our school children to the new school referred to earlier, over this high bridge and road, in my judgment, it is beyond human comprehension that

text.snippet: the North from main <mark>Highway</mark> <mark>460</mark>, such an unreasonable rise

highlights.snippet: the North from main <mark>Highway</mark> <mark>460</mark>, such an unreasonable rise

document.text: pushy. Somehow or other he didnt relish the thought of having to explain that kind of landlady to his wife not that she had ever had anything to worry about, but why rock the boat? Suddenly he thought,. This is sheer nonsense, TO just call, make an appointment, and see for myself. With a hesitant manner, he dialed the number. After just a few rings, the young man heard a soft, hello at the other end of the line. It definitely was not the voice of a cantankerous old lady, nor was it the voice of a sexy siren! It was a lovely voice, gentle, but at the same time with a suggestion of strength. Was he relived! He made an appoint ment for the next evening and he felt sure he would not be disappointed. He was not, he met a lovely lady. A vistor looking for the home of Mama Rach, M rs. Rachel F . Law son, on Lee Street, Appomattox, would find a big two story house with wide front porch. The house, like the inhabitant has about it an friendly air, it sort of seems to say, welcome, come on in. Rachel Ferguson Lawson, a daughter of the late State Senator, Samuel L . Ferguson, and Adelia Mann Ferguson, was born and reared in Appomattox County. Her birth place was The Brickhouse on highway 460 just west of , Appom attox.  The Brick- I house, as it was known to everyond, was built by Rachels  father on the land acquired j shortly after he reached manhood. It had once been 1 known as the old Robertson  farm home and later the Martin j farm. The Fergusons lived in the j Brickhouse until 1913 when j they moved to Courtland, the family home on Court Street in the town of Appomattox. Courtland, a story-book home, was begun in 1911, completed in 1913, and dis mantled in 1970. Incidentally, Mama Rach has in her back yard a gazebo, made entirely of wood and brick from the family home, Courtland. The beautiful home, often called a mansion, with the impressive name of Court- land consisted of 32 rooms, four complete bathrooms, three floors above the ground and boasted an elevator. Rachel laughingly recalled the very first night the family hspfij3U-ip y  nejhJp3fe E iiry th iij and they -were so proud oM t A ll of the bathrooms were gleam ing white. One, however, did not remain that way for long. Rachel had a dog, a white poddle named Rooney. While the family was busily getting settled in the new home, Rooney got to rambling, investigating his new quarters.

Many Volunteers Mrs. Ben Marshall is Appomat tox chairman for house to house canvassing. She has named 24 helpers who will be calling on local residents. Mrs. C. T. Moses, Jr., is in charge of donations from businessmen on highway 460, and county chairman Wm. Hunter will be contacting down town businessmen. Other chair men in outlying communities have laid plans for a compre hensive coverage of the county. Appomattox Workers The 24 eonvassers for Appo mattox are as follows Mrs. Ker- mit Campbell, Mrs. Skinny- Wooldridge, Mrs. Bob Montgo mery, Mrs. J. H. McAden, Mrs. Harry Stanley, Mrs. Eugene Franklin, Mrs. Robert Leffers, Mrs. Woodrow Fitzgerald, Mrs. Raymond Hall, Mrs. S. R. Law- son, Mrs. Walter Carson, Mrs. Ottway Guill, Mrs. W. C. Hubb ard, Mrs. Bobby Mitchell, Mrs. Tommy Richardson, Mrs. Ralph King, Mrs. Dick Bass, Mrs. C. B. Rush, Mrs. Bobby Phelps, Mrs. Fred Lawson, Mrs. J. A.
